Teaching

I believe that effective teaching transforms curiosity into understanding and understanding into innovation. My goal is to create engaging, inclusive learning environments where students feel empowered to explore, question, and discover the fascinating world of computer science.

Current Courses

CS 485: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence

Level: Undergraduate • Enrollment: 45 students

This course introduces fundamental concepts in AI including search algorithms, knowledge representation, machine learning basics, and ethical considerations. Students work on hands-on projects using Python and popular AI libraries.

Prerequisites: Data Structures, Statistics
Semester: Fall 2024 • Rating: 4.8/5.0

CS 685: Deep Learning

Level: Graduate • Enrollment: 25 students

Advanced course covering neural network architectures, optimization techniques, and cutting-edge research in deep learning. Emphasis on both theoretical foundations and practical implementation of modern deep learning systems.

Prerequisites: Machine Learning, Linear Algebra
Semester: Fall 2024 • Rating: 4.9/5.0

CS 580: AI Ethics and Society

Level: Mixed (Undergrad/Grad) • Enrollment: 35 students

Interdisciplinary course examining the societal implications of AI technology. Topics include algorithmic bias, privacy, transparency, and the future of work. Features guest lectures from industry experts and ethicists.

Prerequisites: Intro to AI or equivalent
Semester: Spring 2024 • Rating: 4.7/5.0

Teaching Philosophy

Active Learning & Engagement

I believe that students learn best when they're actively engaged with the material. My classes feature interactive discussions, collaborative problem-solving sessions, and hands-on coding exercises. Instead of passive lectures, students participate in live coding demonstrations and peer programming activities.

I use tools like interactive polling, breakout discussions, and real-time collaborative coding to ensure every student is involved in the learning process. This approach has consistently resulted in higher engagement and better learning outcomes.

Inclusive & Accessible Education

Creating an inclusive classroom environment is paramount to my teaching philosophy. I work actively to ensure that students from all backgrounds feel welcome and supported. This includes using diverse examples in coursework, providing multiple ways to engage with content, and being mindful of different learning styles.

I provide comprehensive accessibility accommodations and maintain flexible policies that recognize students' diverse circumstances. My goal is to remove barriers to learning so that every student can succeed regardless of their background or challenges.

Project-Based Learning

I strongly believe in learning by doing. Each of my courses features substantial project components where students apply theoretical concepts to real-world problems. Students have created everything from chatbots for mental health support to bias-detection tools for hiring systems.

These projects not only reinforce learning but also build portfolios that students can showcase to potential employers. Many of my students' projects have led to internship opportunities, research publications, and even startup ventures.

Educational Resources

Open Educational Resources

All my course materials are made freely available to promote accessible education:

  • Comprehensive lecture slides with interactive elements
  • Video tutorials and coding walkthroughs
  • Practice problems with detailed solutions
  • Project templates and starter code
Usage: Downloaded by 50+ instructors worldwide

Interactive Learning Tools

I've developed several custom tools to enhance the learning experience:

  • Neural Network Visualizer - Interactive tool for understanding deep learning
  • Algorithm Simulator - Step-through visualizations of AI algorithms
  • Ethics Case Study Platform - Interactive scenarios for discussing AI ethics
Impact: Used in 100+ courses globally

Student Success Programs

Beyond formal courses, I run several programs to support student development:

  • Weekly AI Research Seminar for graduate students
  • Undergraduate Research Opportunities Program
  • Industry Mentorship Connections
  • Graduate School Preparation Workshops
Participants: 80+ students annually

Previously Taught Courses

CS 201: Data Structures and Algorithms

Undergraduate Course • 2020-2023 • Average Rating: 4.6/5.0

Foundational course covering essential data structures (arrays, linked lists, trees, graphs) and algorithms (sorting, searching, dynamic programming). Emphasized both theoretical analysis and practical implementation skills.

Innovation: Introduced gamified programming challenges that increased student engagement by 35%

CS 350: Software Engineering

Undergraduate Course • 2019-2022 • Average Rating: 4.5/5.0

Comprehensive course on software development methodologies, project management, testing strategies, and collaborative development using modern tools and practices.

Innovation: Partnered with local nonprofits for real-world project experience, resulting in 12 deployed applications

CS 795: Advanced Topics in Machine Learning

Graduate Seminar • 2021-2023 • Average Rating: 4.8/5.0

Research-focused seminar covering cutting-edge topics in ML including meta-learning, few-shot learning, and neural architecture search. Students presented recent papers and conducted original research projects.

Outcome: 8 student projects resulted in conference submissions, 3 were accepted

Student Support

Office Hours & Availability

Location: Computer Science Building, Room 314

I maintain an open-door policy and encourage students to reach out whenever they need assistance. Whether you're struggling with course material, considering research opportunities, or seeking career advice, I'm here to help you succeed.

Upcoming Courses

CS 590: Responsible AI Development

Launch: Spring 2025 • Level: Graduate

New interdisciplinary course focusing on the technical and social aspects of developing AI systems responsibly. Will cover fairness-aware ML, privacy-preserving techniques, and stakeholder engagement methods.

CS 480: Green Computing and Sustainable AI

Launch: Fall 2025 • Level: Undergraduate

Emerging course addressing the environmental impact of computing and AI. Students will learn about energy-efficient algorithms, carbon-aware computing, and sustainable software development practices.
